meanings.definition: To establish a colony in (a place).
meanings.sent1: The explorers colonised the new land, building homes and farms.
meanings.sent2: Many European countries colonised various regions around the world in the past.
meanings.sent3: The ants colonised the picnic area, claiming all the crumbs for themselves.
meanings.sent4: Her love for gardening colonised every corner of her backyard, turning it into a lush paradise.
meanings.sent5: The idea of starting a new business colonised his mind, driving him to take action.

meanings.definition: To settle in (a place) as a colony.
meanings.sent1: Families from different countries colonised the small island, creating a diverse community.
meanings.sent2: The early settlers colonised the harsh land, adapting to its challenges.
meanings.sent3: The group of friends jokingly decided to colonise the local park for their weekend hangout spot.
meanings.sent4: Her laughter colonised the room, filling it with joy and warmth.
meanings.sent5: The music festival colonised the town, bringing in crowds of excited attendees.

meanings.definition: To subject (a place) to political control and exploit its resources.
meanings.sent1: The powerful empire colonised the neighboring lands, imposing its laws and taxes.
meanings.sent2: During the gold rush, many prospectors colonised the riverbanks in search of riches.
meanings.sent3: The squirrels seemed to have colonised the backyard, storing nuts in every nook and cranny.
meanings.sent4: His ambition colonised his actions, driving him to climb the corporate ladder.
meanings.sent5: The invasive species quickly colonised the forest, disrupting the ecosystem.
